content.body: Noam Rosenthal: I double checked; WebKit would object to exposing that information as we think revealing the precise text an end user might be looking at too revealing
content.formatted_body: Noam Rosenthal: I double checked; WebKit would object to exposing that information as we think revealing the precise text an end user might be looking at too revealing

content.body: annevk: that behavior in navigation timing also exists in Safari
content.formatted_body: annevk: that behavior in navigation timing also exists in Safari

content.body: Ouch, I should have double checked that.
I guess this is not yet covered by WPT?
annevk: all good, let's find a way where fixing the privacy issue doesn't create both a backwards compat issue *and* an interop issue
content.formatted_body: annevk: all good, let's find a way where fixing the privacy issue doesn't create both a backwards compat issue and an interop issue

content.body: annevk: no WPT yet. https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40136467 is the chromium bug
content.formatted_body: annevk: no WPT yet. https://issues.chromium.org/issues/40136467 is the chromium bug

content.body:
annevk: About https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Request/cache#:~:text=If%20there%20is%20no%20match%2C%20the%20browser%20will%20respond%20with%20a%20504%20Gateway%20timeout%20status.
> `only-if-cached` — The browser looks for a matching request in its HTTP cache.
> - If there is a match, fresh or stale, it will be returned from the cache.
> - **If there is no match, the browser will respond with a [504 Gateway timeout](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/504) status.**

Do UAs (any) actually do that? I’ve can’t recall the Fetch spec ever specifying that. Maybe it’s in some other spec?
content.formatted_body:
annevk: About https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Request/cache#:~:text=If%20there%20is%20no%20match%2C%20the%20browser%20will%20respond%20with%20a%20504%20Gateway%20timeout%20status.

only-if-cached — The browser looks for a matching request in its HTTP cache.

  • If there is a match, fresh or stale, it will be returned from the cache.
  • If there is no match, the browser will respond with a 504 Gateway timeout status.

Do UAs (any) actually do that? I’ve can’t recall the Fetch spec ever specifying that. Maybe it’s in some other spec?

content.body:
* annevk: About https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Request/cache#:~:text=If%20there%20is%20no%20match%2C%20the%20browser%20will%20respond%20with%20a%20504%20Gateway%20timeout%20status.

> `only-if-cached` — The browser looks for a matching request in its HTTP cache.
> 
> - If there is a match, fresh or stale, it will be returned from the cache.
> - **If there is no match, the browser will respond with a [504 Gateway timeout](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Status/504) status.**

Do UAs (any) actually do that? I’ve can’t recall the Fetch spec ever specifying that. Maybe it’s in some other spec?
Did the Fetch spec ever say it should return anything other than a network error?
